reviewText:
VCI Entertainment and Universal Pictures present "Silver Bullet" (1942) (digitally remastered), long running Johnny Mack Brown series turned out in the early '40s...our story opens with Johnny Mack Brown stopping the stagecoach only to ask the passengers to roll up their left sleeve...many years ago a lone rider killed his father and shot him with a silver bullet, only during the fight he saw the lightning scar on his arm...LeRoy Mason is that man, he goes to William Farnum who is the local doctor and requests the removal of the scar, during that operation Mason kills him so he won't talk...Fuzzy Knight is the comical sidekick who is writing a play for Grace Leonard is girlfriend who is a saloon owner...Rex Lease is in with Mason and they are up to no good for the senate election, which Mason wants very badly...Jennifer Holt is backing Claire Whitney who is the widow of William Farnum so they can have an honest candidate...watch for the gunfight at the end of the film, see if Johnny Mack can come up a winner once again in this Universal hayseed....just remember double thrills, chills, mystery and suspense...hitting the bull's eye with excitement...don't miss any of Johnny Mack Brown's Double Features loaded with action that will leave you wanting more of his B-Western adventures.

Under director Joseph H. Lewis, associate producer Oliver Drake, screenplay by Elizabeth Beecher, original story by Oliver Drake, musical director H. J. Salter, original songs by Oliver Drake, Milton Rosen and Jimmy Wakely ...the cast include Johnny Mack Brown (Silver Jim Donovan), Fuzzy Knight (Wild Bill Jones), William Farnum (Dr. Thad Morgan), Jennifer Holt (Nancy Lee), LeRoy Mason (Walter Kincaid), Rex Lease (Rance Harris), Grace Lenard (Queenie Canfield), Claire Whitney ( Emily Morgan), Slim Whitaker (Buck/henchman), Pals of the Golden West (Singing Ensemble), Nora Lou Martin (Nora, Singer, Pals of the Golden West), Lloyd Ingraham (Coroner), Williams Desmond (townsmen) . . . . . .first special footnote, Fuzzy Knight was the sidekick with his comical ways in many B-Westerns in the '30s & '40s with Johnny Mack Brown and Tex Ritter, finally landing a co-starring role with Buster Crabbe on the small tube in the TV series "Captain Gallant of the Foreign Legion" (1955) as Private Fuzzy Knight. . . . . . . .second footnote, actor LeRoy Mason was always the "big boss" and the well dressed heavy in B-Westerns during the '30s and '40s...worked with Gene Autry, Bob Baker, Don Barry, Johnny Mack Brown, Sunset Carson, Ray "Crash" Corrigan, Monte Hale, Tim Holt, Tom Keene, Rocky Lane, Bob Livingston, George O'Brien, Range Busters, Roy Rogers and 3 Mesquiteers...Mason worked in thirteen serials "Last Frontier" (1932), "Phantom of the Air" (1933), "Painted Stallion" (1937), "Jungle Menace" (1937), "Tiger Woman" (1944), "Phantom Rider" (1946) and "Daughter of Don Q" (1946)... Mason was under exclusive contract from  1943 until is untimely death in '47.........check out this and more in a new book "Best of the Badmen" by Boyd Magers, Bob Nareau and Bobby Copeland, available from Amazon and Empire Publishing. . . pick up your copy today........the final special footnote actor Johnny Mack Brown had a long film association with producer A.W. Hackel in a series of B-Westerns for Universal Pictures, many directed by Ray Taylor...A. William Hackel also produced a series of Bob Steele B-Westerns........meanwhile this is an exciting Johnny Mack Brown western provided by Universal Pictures during their heyday of the early '40s.

Ask Amazon. Com to carry the above five titles as they are not available on Amazon as of yet...you can order and pick up your copy now from VCI Entertainment...if you enjoyed "Silver Bullet" (1942), why not pick up other copies of Johnny Mack Brown Double Features.

Bobby J. Copeland's book on "Johnny Mack Brown: Up Close & Personal" is chuck full of answers to all the questions his fans had from early on...when you went to see him on the big screen, you got exactly what the marquee said...plenty of thrills, adventure and loaded with action...Johnny Mack was a natural for the western, his riding abilities and fight scenes were of the the same caliber as Buck Jones and Bob Steele...Johnny Mack sets the saddle better than Duke Wayne...seems Johnny got better with the more films he made and the scripts were always top notch...he was one of the best-liked people in films, what you saw on the screen is what he really was, a great human being...pickup your copy from Amazon or Empire Publishing both have this in stock.

Great job by VCI Entertainment for releasing "Silver Bullet" (1942), the digital transfere with a clean, clear and crisp print...looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '30s, '40s & '50s...order your copy now from Amazon or VCI Entertainment where there are plenty of copies available on DVD and VHS, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure from the "King of Serials" VCI...just the way we like 'em

Total Time: 56 min on VHS ~ VCI Entertainment #1275 ~ (12/17/2002)
